decision_conditions: All the applied for trees are situated within the rear garden of 85 Copsewood Way, as a group they have a Moderate to high amenity value and significantly contribute to the Arboricultural character of the Copsewood Estate (Area of Special Local Character). They provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in the copse wood estate and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR).

The Oak closest to the property (Tree 1 on application) is showing signs of dieback, a reduction by 50% is very drastic and there is no Arboricultural evidence that this is appropriate management for this tree, the removal of deadwood is exempt from the TPO application process and can be removed at any time, the resident may wish to discuss the future management this tree with an Arboricultural Consultant (a new application would be needed if they recommend work).
The other seven trees (Oak and Hornbeams) appear to be in good health and have natural looking crowns for their
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.

Expert assessment: The Oak (Tree 1 on application) is showing signs of die-back in its canopy. Expert assessment should be made to determine the cause of this and if there is decay present, and if so how extensive it is in terms of the condition, safety and management of the tree.
description: To carry out tree surgery including, a crown reduction by 50% Two Oaks (trees 1 and 2 on application), a crown reduction by 40% Four Hornbeams (Trees 3, 4, 5 and 7 on application and One Oak (Tree 8 on application) and a crown reduction by 30% One Oak (Tree 6 on application), all within Area 1 on TPO 389.
